issues.description: Attribute type mismatch for Person.birthday across artifacts. The problem statement (UML) and the template's Person model declare birthday as java.time.LocalDate, but the solution's Person model declares birthday as String. This divergence will confuse students about the expected type and how to interact with DatePicker/serialization, and it can cause runtime/compile issues when converting between LocalDate and String in controllers and services.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Person.birthday type consistent across artifacts. Prefer restoring birthday to java.time.LocalDate in the solution repository (to match the problem statement and template), and adjust any service/controller serialization code accordingly. Alternatively, if the teaching intent is to use String for birthday, update the problem statement, template (Person model), and UI code (PersonScene DatePicker usage) to use String consistently, and document how conversion between LocalDate and String should be handled.

issues.description: Internal inconsistency in the solution repository: the client UI (PersonScene) expects Person.getBirthday() to be a LocalDate (it uses DatePicker.setValue(LocalDate/...)), but the solution's shared Person model declares birthday as String. This creates a compile-time/type mismatch between the view and model within the solution codebase and will prevent the solution code from compiling or running as-is.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution consistent: change Person.getBirthday()/setBirthday() in the solution's common Person model back to java.time.LocalDate so the PersonScene DatePicker usage compiles. If instead the model should remain String, update PersonScene to convert between String and LocalDate when setting/getting the DatePicker value and ensure all client/service code performs the conversion consistently.
